response.answer_text: Entrepreneurship is basically the creation of a new enterprise to achieve some objective. It’s the creation and management of a new enterprise. Do entrepreneurs work to make money? No, not necessarily. They want to create value, and the value could be based on money, or it could be based on service or some sort of a mission. So I think value, if you create value and the value happens to be financial, then you're making money.Well, it could also act as a bridge though. People can choose to go into entrepreneurship either because they're forced to do it between other things or because they want to try and engage in something new themselves that fulfills some personal goal or value as well.So I think this notion of creating and managing an enterprise is probably appropriate but, I think entrepreneurship, in general, could be much broader than that.I mean, we're talking about corporate entrepreneurship, it's not necessarily creating a new enterprise.There's also entrepreneurship at the individual levels. I think to me it's about taking initiative and thinking out of the box and starting something new. And so it means different things for different people. How is that different from innovation more broadly? Is it the same as innovation? I mean that sounds like a definition of innovation? So in our tedious world of academic debate over this, there is an ongoing debate over whether it's about the opportunity or discovery of opportunity, it doesn't need to be an innovation. Right, it can be an existing market that you're going into, and the debate is now whether the opportunities are discovered or created. So innovation is about creating some new opportunities. But you could discover that there is no coffee shop in your neighborhood, right? You don't have to innovate to necessarily do that and find an opportunity to act. Taking the Uber concept to Pakistan, would be entrepreneurship and not necessarily innovation in that definition.

An Entrepreneur is someone who takes a risk in starting a business to earn a profit. Entrepreneurship is the process of starting, organizing, managing and assuming responsibility for a business. Entrepreneur Characteristics Problem solving skillsTolerance for ambiguityPersonal initiativeStrong integrityAbility to secure resourcesCapability to learn from failureAbility be innovativeWillingness to work hardHow to be innovative? Better than (higher quality), Different than (unique qualities), and Cheaper than (more affordable). Trends - A general direction that something is developing or changing. 5 Types of Businesses Retail => Sells products directly to those who use or consume them.Wholesale => Sells products to other businesses rather than a final consumer.Service => Sells acts of assistance (a service) rather than products.Manufacturing => Uses resources and supplies to produce products.Agriculture and mining => Agriculture: generating fresh produce. Mining: taking resources out of the ground.3 Main Types of Business Ownership Proprietorship => A business owned and run by just one person.Partnership => A business is owned and controlled by two or more people who have entered into a written agreement.Corporation => A separate legal entity formed by documents filed with your state. Owned by one or more shareholders and managed by a board of directors.Specialized Types of Ownership FranchiseChainJoint VentureFranchises A written contract granting permission to operate a business to sell products and service in a set way. Franchiser - the company that owns the product or service and grants the rights.Franchisee - the company purchasing the rights to run the business: Franchisee pays a fee and percentage of the profits to the franchisor in return for operating assistance.Top Franchise McDonald’sDunkin’Sonic Drive-InTaco BellThe UPS StoreCulver’sPlanet FitnessGreat ClipsJersey Mike’s Subs7-Eleven Inc.Chains A group of one or more stores that have the same name, sell the same products and follow the same corporate policies. A chain is corporate owned, the parent corporation owns all of the stores or units. They run the day-to-day operationsThey gain or loss the profits or losses of each unitExample: Portillos’s Joint Venture A unique business organized by two or more other businesses to operate for a limited time and for a specific project. Example: Flat + Google = Self Driving Cars Sources of Financing Bank loansFamily & FriendsCrowd-fundingDonationsVenture Capitalists: large investors who provide money to finance new products (aka shark tank)Missons & Goals Mission Statement - a short, specific written statement of the reason a business exists and what it wants to achieve.Goal - a precise statement of results the business expects to achieve: goals are used to define what needs to be accomplished and determine if the business is successfulNeeded to give direction to people within the workplaceExample: Starbucks Mission Statement - “Our mission is to inspire & nurture the human spirit—one person, one cup, and one neighborhood”. Core Values Core values are an important piece of your foundational content that your staff should know and identify withCore values are the guiding principles that dictate behavior and actionCore values help companies determine if they are on the right path and fulfilling their business goalsElements of the Business Plan Description of the BusinessMarket AnalysisCustomer AnalysisOperations PlanLayoutMarketing PlanFinancial Plan
